'Hullabaloo' Bills
Due Says Austrian
Robert Austrian, editor of the
Hullabaloo, announced today that
all Fraternity, Senior's and Sports'
bills due must be paid by the end
of the week, as the book is going
to press before May 1.
The bills may be paid to Henry
Kramer, business manager of the
Hullabaloo, between 12 and 1 in
the Hullabaloo office any day now.
"Prompt payment by these
groups for space will make possible price discounts, which will
result in a larger and better year
book," said Kramer.

Because of the lack of discussion on this particular
case, grave and serious suspicions and conclusions are
produced. It is a shame that this student, after a
full college career of distinguished academic attainment
should not have even been given benefit of discussion.
It is an injustice to him and an indirect slap in the face
at the judgment of the Executive Committee.
Students, like U13, are unable to understand the rejection when we consider the qualification necessary and
the qualifications possessed by this undergraduate. Because of the lack of any discussion or any charges, it is
made to seem likely that outside factors had intervened.
But what we are interested in is what to do about it.
First let us say that this case demands reconsideration.
Yes, we are aware that the chapter constitution does
not provide for such a procedure. But action can be
taken if the chapter meets again and examines carefully
all possibilities.
There is also the matter of a recurrence of the
present unfortunate situation. It is clear that some
reform in the method of selecting Phi Beta Kappa members is needed. We suggest either a two-thirds or
majority vote.
Our opinion in no way constitutes an indictment of
the Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. We are more
convinced than ever of the high calibre and fair-mindedness which characterized all officers and members whom
we interviewed.
But what we strongly condemn are the conditions
which allowed such a case as this to arise.

contains, also, a large smoking room
and refreshment as well as locker
rooms and showers. One wing of
the building is reserved for the use
of women members.
On March 29th an "Open-House"
was given for members of the faculty. Dinner was served to 100 of the
300 present on that evening. On the
first of April a second informal
gathering, this time of the Alumni,
was held. 114 persons partook of dinner on that occasion. Later, refreshments were served. No formal dedication has as yet taken place.
Mrs. Grace C. Fisher, manageress
of the club, said, "The club is for the
benefit of faculty and alumni. Meals
will be served at moderate prices to
members, and every effort to make
them comfortable here will be
made."
The club is not open to the public,
and its use is restricted wholly to
members and their guests. Membership is open to all men and women
who are members of the teaching
staff of the University, and of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, and to all
graduate students and alumni of the
University. The other requirement
is that an application for admission
must be accompanied by the endorsement of two club members.
The Board of Governors plans to
keep the club open for eleven months
in the year. The officers are: President, R. G. Merrick; vice-president,
G. E. Barnett; secretary, W. B. Kouwenhoven, and treasurer, A. C. Howard.

Dr. James Kendall, professor of
chemistry at the University of Edinburgh, will speak before a meeting
of the Maryland branch of the Amer:
ican Chemical Society at 8.15 P. M.
this evening in room 58, Rowland
Hall. His subject will be "Liquids
and Solutions."
Dr. Kendall, born in Surrey, England, on June 30, 1889, was educated
at the University of Edinburgh,
where he took his doctor's degree in
1915. Having decided to do graduate
work, he then went to the Nobel Institute in Stockholm for a brief period.
He was a member of the Faculty of
Columbia
University from 1913
to 1926, when he left to become professor of chemistry at Washington
Square College.
He remained in America until
1928, when he went to Edinburgh to
take the position he now holds.
His speech will be a summary of
the papers and discussions of the
Faraday Society which met last September in Edinburgh.

Y. T. Wu, former National Secretary of the Student Division of the
Y. M. C. A. an editor-in-chief of the
Chinese Division of the Associated
Press, will be the guest speaker at
the Student Christian Association
Meeting of Maryland Colleges at Levering Hall tomorrow. Students from
Goucher, Maryland State Teachers
College, Morgan College, Maryland
College for Women, and Hopkins
will take part in the conference.
At 4.00, Mr. Wu will lead a Round
Table discussion for "Y" Cabinet
members on "The Christian Revolution." The speaker is one of the
leaders of the Christian movements
in the East, and is said to be one of
the foremost interpreters of the Chinese movement.
At the evening meeting at 7.30,
Mr. Wu will speak on "My Conception of God." The meeting will be
open tol all faculty, students, and
friends of the University, and will
be held at Levering Hall.
As editor-in-chief of the Associated Press, Mr. Wu has built up a
group of Chinese writers whose production, during the past few years,
is regarded as notable and who have
atempted to put forward a comprehensive and coordinated program of
literature production, especially for
educated Chinese youth. His major
contributions have been in the field of
interpreting the meaning, the discipline and the social implications of
Christianity.

The Johns Hopkins University
baseball team defeated the Towson
Teachers in its first game last Saturday at the Gilman School by the
score of 9 to 5.
The Indians scored first in the second inning, but the Hopkins team
erased that lead in their half of the
second inning and scored again in
the third and sixth innings. However
Normal team took the lead again in
their half of the eighth by scoring
three runs and leading 4 to 3. In
their half of the eighth inning the
Hopkins team staged a six run rally
in which each better got one turn
at the plate.
Jays Score In 8th
John Carper, Hopkins center fielder, led the attack with three outs
out of four trips to the plate. It was
his hit in the second inning that set
the stage for the first run, when
Alperstein laid down a sacrifice bunt
to advance Carper to second, and
Carper scored when Romanofsky
came through with a single. Again,
when the Jays were behind in the
eight inning it was Carper's third
hit that started the six run rally
which meant the victory for Hopkins.
Len Rubinger was credited with
the victory and pitched the full nine
innings. He was nicked for nine hits
and gave ten walks, but struck out
nine men.
The Jays' next opponent will be
Mount St. Mary's team and the game
is scheduled for this Saturday, at
3 p.m., probably at the Gilman School
diamond.

If you've heard this story before,
it's your own fault. If you haven't,
have a laugh at the expense of our
ever belittled trainer, Jimmy Benson.

of sticks, hickory against heads, and
the outbursts of the outsiders. Suddenly a figure drops with an accompanying shriek of agony. . . . Pete
Swindell is down with a limp leg. . .
His head goes from side to side. . . .
he's drooling at the mouth.

1 -6

5-0;

The Hopkins team previously defeated Penn on the Homewood courts
5-1. Arnold "Red" Glantz supplied
the only Jay victory on the Penn
courts.
The team ended a highly successful season with seven wins and two
losses. The team is captained by
Nathaniel Finkelstein and coached
by Reuben Baer.
Jays Sweep Singles
In the first singles match with
Western Maryland, Milt Alperstein
defeated Joe Dickson 15-11, 15-12 in
a hard-fought match with Alperstein's better condition, giving him
the edge.
Dick Pasternak overwhelmed Bill Harston 15-5, 15-6 in
the second singles, while Captain
Finkelstein completed the sweep of
the singles by defeating Dan Volkhart 15-8, 15-9.
In the doubles, Pasternak paired
with Rossett, a newcomer on the
team, to beat Johnson and Daly of
Western Maryland, 15-8, 15-6. The
Westminster team forfeited the last
doubles matc)11 to Alperstein and
Finkelstein.
Pasternak Injured
In the first singles at Penn, Iry
Milberg lost a hard-fought match to
John Anderson 21-19, 21-9. The secong singles match was called off after
Slick Pasternak of Hopkins split a
finger bone when leading Rockmore
of Penn, 18-12. Milt Alperstein lost
a long drawn-out struggle to "Blimp"
Wolinsky of Penn 21-15, 21-19 in the
third singles. "Red" Glantz provided
the only Hopkins victory by playing
a great game of ball to turn aside
Wade of Penn 21-16, 21-12. Glantz's
superior speed afoot clinched this
battle.
Penn Takes Doubles
Milberg and Alperstein lost the
first doubles after winning the first
game 21-18, but dropped the next two
21-17
23-21. Glantz and Finkelstein bowed in the second doubles
18-21, 21-15, 17-21.

'Hullabaloo' Bills
Due Says Austrian
Robert Austrian, editor of the
Hullabaloo, announced today that
all Fraternity, Senior's and Sports'
bills due must be paid by the end
of the week, as the book is going
to press before May 1.
The bills may be paid to Henry
Kramer, business manager of the
Hullabaloo, between 12 and 1 in
the Hullabaloo office any day now.
"Prompt payment by these
groups for space will make possible price discounts, which will
result in a larger and better year
book," said Kramer.

Because of the lack of discussion on this particular
case, grave and serious suspicions and conclusions are
produced. It is a shame that this student, after a
full college career of distinguished academic attainment
should not have even been given benefit of discussion.
It is an injustice to him and an indirect slap in the face
at the judgment of the Executive Committee.
Students, like U13, are unable to understand the rejection when we consider the qualification necessary and
the qualifications possessed by this undergraduate. Because of the lack of any discussion or any charges, it is
made to seem likely that outside factors had intervened.
But what we are interested in is what to do about it.
First let us say that this case demands reconsideration.
Yes, we are aware that the chapter constitution does
not provide for such a procedure. But action can be
taken if the chapter meets again and examines carefully
all possibilities.
There is also the matter of a recurrence of the
present unfortunate situation. It is clear that some
reform in the method of selecting Phi Beta Kappa members is needed. We suggest either a two-thirds or
majority vote.
Our opinion in no way constitutes an indictment of
the Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. We are more
convinced than ever of the high calibre and fair-mindedness which characterized all officers and members whom
we interviewed.
But what we strongly condemn are the conditions
which allowed such a case as this to arise.

On March 29th an "Open-House"
was given for members of the faculty. Dinner was served to 100 of the
300 present on that evening. On the
first of April a second informal
gathering, this time of the Alumni,
was held. 114 persons partook of dinner on that occasion. Later, refreshments were served. No formal dedication has as yet taken place.
Mrs. Grace C. Fisher, manageress
of the club, said, "The club is for the
benefit of faculty and alumni. Meals
will be served at moderate prices to
members, and every effort to make
them comfortable here will be
made."
The club is not open to the public,
and its use is restricted wholly to
members and their guests. Membership is open to all men and women
who are members of the teaching
staff of the University, and of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, and to all
graduate students and alumni of the
University. The other requirement
is that an application for admission
must be accompanied by the endorsement of two club members.
The Board of Governors plans to
keep the club open for eleven months
in the year. The officers are: President, R. G. Merrick; vice-president,
G. E. Barnett; secretary, W. B. Kouwenhoven, and treasurer, A. C. Howard.

Dr. James Kendall, professor of
chemistry at the University of Edinburgh, will speak before a meeting
of the Maryland branch of the Amer:
ican Chemical Society at 8.15 P. M.
this evening in room 58, Rowland
Hall. His subject will be "Liquids
and Solutions."
Dr. Kendall, born in Surrey, England, on June 30, 1889, was educated
at the University of Edinburgh,
where he took his doctor's degree in
1915. Having decided to do graduate
work, he then went to the Nobel Institute in Stockholm for a brief period.
He was a member of the Faculty of
Columbia
University from 1913
to 1926, when he left to become professor of chemistry at Washington
Square College.
He remained in America until
1928, when he went to Edinburgh to
take the position he now holds.
His speech will be a summary of
the papers and discussions of the
Faraday Society which met last September in Edinburgh.

Y. T. Wu, former National Secretary of the Student Division of the
Y. M. C. A. an editor-in-chief of the
Chinese Division of the Associated
Press, will be the guest speaker at
the Student Christian Association
Meeting of Maryland Colleges at Levering Hall tomorrow. Students from
Goucher, Maryland State Teachers
College, Morgan College, Maryland
College for Women, and Hopkins
will take part in the conference.
At 4.00, Mr. Wu will lead a Round
Table discussion for "Y" Cabinet
members on "The Christian Revolution." The speaker is one of the
leaders of the Christian movements
in the East, and is said to be one of
the foremost interpreters of the Chinese movement.
At the evening meeting at 7.30,
Mr. Wu will speak on "My Conception of God." The meeting will be
open tol all faculty, students, and
friends of the University, and will
be held at Levering Hall.
As editor-in-chief of the Associated Press, Mr. Wu has built up a
group of Chinese writers whose production, during the past few years,
is regarded as notable and who have
atempted to put forward a comprehensive and coordinated program of
literature production, especially for
educated Chinese youth. His major
contributions have been in the field of
interpreting the meaning, the discipline and the social implications of
Christianity.

The Johns Hopkins University
baseball team defeated the Towson
Teachers in its first game last Saturday at the Gilman School by the
score of 9 to 5.
The Indians scored first in the second inning, but the Hopkins team
erased that lead in their half of the
second inning and scored again in
the third and sixth innings. However
Normal team took the lead again in
their half of the eighth by scoring
three runs and leading 4 to 3. In
their half of the eighth inning the
Hopkins team staged a six run rally
in which each better got one turn
at the plate.
Jays Score In 8th
John Carper, Hopkins center fielder, led the attack with three outs
out of four trips to the plate. It was
his hit in the second inning that set
the stage for the first run, when
Alperstein laid down a sacrifice bunt
to advance Carper to second, and
Carper scored when Romanofsky
came through with a single. Again,
when the Jays were behind in the
eight inning it was Carper's third
hit that started the six run rally
which meant the victory for Hopkins.
Len Rubinger was credited with
the victory and pitched the full nine
innings. He was nicked for nine hits
and gave ten walks, but struck out
nine men.
The Jays' next opponent will be
Mount St. Mary's team and the game
is scheduled for this Saturday, at
3 p.m., probably at the Gilman School
diamond.

The Hopkins team previously defeated Penn on the Homewood courts
5-1. Arnold "Red" Glantz supplied
the only Jay victory on the Penn
courts.
The team ended a highly successful season with seven wins and two
losses. The team is captained by
Nathaniel Finkelstein and coached
by Reuben Baer.
Jays Sweep Singles
In the first singles match with
Western Maryland, Milt Alperstein
defeated Joe Dickson 15-11, 15-12 in
a hard-fought match with Alperstein's better condition, giving him
the edge.
Dick Pasternak overwhelmed Bill Harston 15-5, 15-6 in
the second singles, while Captain
Finkelstein completed the sweep of
the singles by defeating Dan Volkhart 15-8, 15-9.
In the doubles, Pasternak paired
with Rossett, a newcomer on the
team, to beat Johnson and Daly of
Western Maryland, 15-8, 15-6. The
Westminster team forfeited the last
doubles matc)11 to Alperstein and
Finkelstein.
Pasternak Injured
In the first singles at Penn, Iry
Milberg lost a hard-fought match to
John Anderson 21-19, 21-9. The secong singles match was called off after
Slick Pasternak of Hopkins split a
finger bone when leading Rockmore
of Penn, 18-12. Milt Alperstein lost
a long drawn-out struggle to "Blimp"
Wolinsky of Penn 21-15, 21-19 in the
third singles. "Red" Glantz provided
the only Hopkins victory by playing
a great game of ball to turn aside
Wade of Penn 21-16, 21-12. Glantz's
superior speed afoot clinched this
battle.
Penn Takes Doubles
Milberg and Alperstein lost the
first doubles after winning the first
game 21-18, but dropped the next two
21-17
23-21. Glantz and Finkelstein bowed in the second doubles
18-21, 21-15, 17-21.
